title: James Turner speaks with the press, May 3, 1968

collection: Records of the Bursar’s Office Takeover, May 1968
description: Northwestern University students join in solidarity with approximately 120 Black Northwestern University students occupying the Bursar's Office as a means to compel the campus administration to address discriminatory campus policies and to heighten awareness of Black students' experiences of alienation at Northwestern University. By sitting on the steps of the building, students outside of the building were physically blocking the entry way to prevent an incident of police forcibly removing students inside. They also held signs reinforcing members of FMO and AASU's April 22, 1968 demands to the administration. The sign to the left states, "Black students occupy this building because the administration has turned a deaf ear." The sign to the right states, "Black autonomy Black self-determination."

collection: Records of the Bursar’s Office Takeover, May 1968
contributor: Ogletree, Kathryn|Nzinga-Johnson, Sekile, 1971-|Wilson, Charla|Glover, Tay|Northwestern University Libraries|Northwestern University Women's Center
creator: Northwestern University (Evanston, Ill.)
description: Kathryn Ogletree (WCAS’71, TGS’76) reflects on the Bursar's Office Takeover at Northwestern University in 1968. Ogletree was one of more than 100 African American student activists who occupied the Bursar’s Office for 38 hours to protest the state of Black student’s experiences at Northwestern. Kathryn Ogletree was a leader in the Bursar's Office Takeover and served as the president of FMO (For Members Only). She was instrumental in advocating for African American student’s demands to Northwestern University’s administration. The Bursar's Office Takeover ended with the “May 4th Agreement,” a negotiated solution that promised increased black student enrollment, financial aid and black history and culture studies and the establishment of the Black House.  In March 2018, Ogletree was invited back to campus as part of the Women’s Center’s 30th anniversary and the commemoration of the 50th anniversary of 1968 Bursar’s Office Takeover.  She discussed the role of women in student activism for an audience of about 50 at Harris Hall. The director of Northwestern University Women's Center, Dr. Sekile Nzinga Johnson, PhD, MSW introduces the program and provides a brief history of Northwestern's Women's Center. Charla Wilson, Archivist for the Black Experience at Northwestern University Libraries, speaks about the context and significance of having Kathryn Ogletree speak about the takeover from her perspective. Graduate student, Tay Glover, provides a brief biography and introduction of Kathryn Ogletree. Ogletree was awarded the Women’s Center’s Gender Equity in Action Award.
subject: Northwestern University (Evanston, Ill.)|African American college students|Civil rights demonstrations|Student movements|Evanston, Illinois

collection: Records of the Bursar’s Office Takeover, May 1968
contributor: Northwestern University (Evanston, Ill.). Department of University Relations
description:
Some of the images display Black Northwestern University students who chose not to enter the Bursar's Office during the Takeover for a number of reasons including the potential of jeopardizing their enrollment status, financial aid, and fear of a violent outcome. As an organization, FMO and AASU members voted to recuse athletes from occupying the building because they had the most to lose if their athletic scholarships were revoked. Some of those athletes are pictured here. The woman to the right holding the sign is Laura Murray. The sign states, "Black students occupy this building because the administration has turned a deaf ear."

Other photos feature James Turner, President of African American Student Union (AASU), and a lead negotiator in the Bursar's Office Takeover holding the list of demands drafted by FMO and AASU and presented to Northwestern administration on April 22, 1968 and speaking with the press. This photo is taken in front of the Bursar's Office on 619 Clark Street in Evanston, IL. Northwestern University student, Stephen Broussard is also pictured with Turner. 

There are photos of a crowd consisting of students, Northwestern staff, and the press gathers in front of the Bursar's Office as approximately 120 Black Northwestern University students occupy the building as a means to compel the campus administration to address discriminatory campus policies and to heighten awareness of Black students' experiences of alienation at Northwestern University.

description: James Turner, President of Afro-American Student Union (AASU), and a lead negotiator in the Bursar's Office Takeover, pictured in the middle while speaking to the press. This photo is taken in front of the Bursar's Office on 619 Clark Street in Evanston, IL.

collection: Records of the Bursar’s Office Takeover, May 1968
description: Throughout the day on Friday, May 3, 1968, James Turner, President of Afro-American Student Union (AASU), and a lead negotiator in the Bursar's Office Takeover, and Jack Hinz, Northwestern University Dean of Students and Vice President, met to negotiate an agreement between FMO, AASU, and the University regarding the April 22 demands presented to the NU by FMO and AASU.

collection: Records of the Bursar’s Office Takeover, May 1968
creator: WNUR (Radio station : Evanston, Ill.)|Northwestern University (Evanston, Ill.)
description: On May 9, 1968, Black student leader James Turner spoke at Northwestern University's Student Symposium 1969, on the topic of “Black Students: After the Crisis,” about the 38-hour sit in by African American students at the University's Bursar's Office, and some of the issues it brought to the forefront of campus dialogue. For more background information on the sit-in, see the digital exhibit at http://exhibits.library.northwestern.edu/archives/exhibits/1968/1968.html and the collection of documents and clippings at http://tinyurl.com/z3mzox8

collection: Records of the Bursar’s Office Takeover, May 1968
contributor: Northwestern University (Evanston, Ill.)|Northwestern University Black Alumni Association|Sterling, Jeffrey E.|Seals, Donnie|Seals, Eric D.|Applegate, Brittany|Lennix, Harry J.|Zo!, 1978-
description: On May 3, 1968, more than 100 Northwestern students peacefully occupied the Bursar’s Office to protest the black student experience. The occupation lasted 38 hours, ending with a negotiated resolution in which the administration responded to a list of eight student demands.
notes: {'note': 'Executive producers: Northwestern University, Northwestern Black Alumni Association. Producer: Brittany Applegate. Director: Eric D. Seals. Writer: Donnie Seals, Jr. Original score: ZO! Narrator: Harry Lennix.', 'type': 'Creation/Production Credits'}

title: The Takeover

collection: Records of the Bursar’s Office Takeover, May 1968
description: Northwestern University students, largely white students pictured here, join in solidarity with approximately 120 Black Northwestern University students occupying the Bursar's Office as a means to compel the campus administration to address discriminatory campus policies and to heighten awareness of Black students' experiences of alienation at Northwestern University. By sitting on the steps of the building, students were physically blocking the entry way to prevent an incident of police forcibly removing students inside.
